misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the loop `for (int i = n - 1; i > 0; i--)` iterates over and shifts every element from the second-to-last position (index n-2) down to the first position (index 1), successfully moving the contents of `arr[i-1]` into `arr[i]`. The student seems to have missed that one element is excluded from the shifting mechanism.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The loop condition `i > 0` causes the loop to terminate when `i` reaches 1. This means the element at index 0 (`arr[0]`) is never shifted (i.e., `arr[1] = arr[0]`) before the last element is placed into `arr[0]`. Consequently, the element at the original `arr[n-2]` is correctly shifted to `arr[n-1]`, but the content of the original `arr[1]` is placed into `arr[2]`, and so on, until the original `arr[1]` is never moved to `arr[0]` (it is overwritten by `last` later). The shift operation should iterate until `i` is 1, so the condition should be `i >= 1` or `i > 0` if `i` is the target index. The current logic is correct for the internal shift.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student correctly implements the array right shift logic: (1) save the last element, (2) iterate backwards from index `n-1` down to index `1` (inclusive) to move elements one position right (`arr[i] = arr[i - 1]`), and (3) place the saved last element into index 0.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: There is no conceptual gap. The code correctly implements the specified right shift and wrap-around. For an array of size 4, the loop runs for i=3 and i=2. i=3: arr[3] = arr[2]. i=2: arr[2] = arr[1]. The element at arr[1] is left alone. Wait, the loop runs for i=3, 2, 1. i=3 (arr[3] = arr[2]). i=2 (arr[2] = arr[1]). i=1 (arr[1] = arr[0]). The loop stops when i=1, so it executes arr[1] = arr[0]. All elements are shifted correctly. The initial categorization was based on a flawed reading of the loop termination condition. The code is logically correct.
